application_process: Most referrals made through Opportunity Council's Coordinated Entry system. Contact the Community Resource Center for intake.
description: 9 bedroom emergency shelter,  serving people who are homeless and have behavioral health issues. Trained staff on-duty 24 hours a day.
name: Sun House

description: Program designed for new parents to attend with their babies, aged 2-16 weeks old, in a family with one or more older children. Groups come together for 2 hours, once a week, for 12 weeks, with time for sharing parenting highs and lows, to focus on the babies' development, and a discussion topic.
fees: Sliding scale, flexible pricing. Call for details.
name: Second Time Around Program

description: Long-Term Care services in the comfort of your own home. Caregiving services, assistance with activities of daily living, nursing services, assistive technology, and even modifications to your house are aspects of in-home care. If you are needing assistance to live safely in your own home and meet income qualifications, you could be eligible to receive in-home care.
fees: NWRC provides access to in-home care under Medicaid. You must apply to DSHS to determine your eligibility to have the costs of care covered by Medicaid. Depending on your income, you may have a co-pay that covers a portion of the cost.
name: In-Home Care - NWRC

description: An 8-hour class that covers all drugs and their effects on the mind, including pertinent laws and consequences of drug use.
name: Alcohol and Drug Information School (ADIS)

application_process: Call for more information.
description: Supports adults with developmental disabilities to live as independently as possible in their own homes and to thrive in their communities. Supports may include, but are not limited to personal care, financial support, budgeting, bill paying, cooking and cleaning, support making and attending medical appointments, positive behavior supports, and community integration.
name: Cascade Connections Supported Living

application_process: Contact the Community Resource Center for screening.
description: Provides housing and support services to those who have served in active military, naval or air service, and their families. The program aims to serve those who are at risk of homelessness or who are homeless.
name: Supportive Services for Veteran Families

application_process: Fill out the Outpatient Services Paperwork available online, return paperwork to Lake Whatcom Center.
description: Intensive Outpatient Program. A home and community-based treatment program for adults experiencing severe and persistent mental health symptoms. IOP offers the opportunity to develop sustainable coping skills, vocational skills, interpersonal skills, and self-awareness of mental health illnesses.
name: IOP Program - LWC

description: Renew, replace or apply for a driver license, ID card, or instruction permit; renew vehicle tabs or boat decals; get new license plates; report a vehicle sale or transfer of ownership; register a vehicle or boat; get a disabled parking placard or tabs; and more.
name: Washington State Department of Licensing

description: Serves students experiencing homelessness. This program is designed to reduce isolation, maximize stability and maintain consistency for this population of children and youth. Contact the liaison in your school district for support.
name: McKinney-Vento Program - BPS

application_process: Call for information
description: If a forensic interview is requested by law enforcement for a child ages 3 - 17 who is a victim of abuse, you will be interviewed by a Child Interview Specialist.
name: Child Forensic Interviews - Dawson Place

description: Provides behavioral health services integrated with medical care, traditional counseling and psychiatric services, support and wellness groups, and case management services to help you access other community resources such as housing, food, and legal assistance.
fees: Apple Health (Medicaid), Medicare, and private insurance accepted. Sliding Fee Discount Program available based on household size and income.
name: Unity Care NW Behavioral Health

description: Community center for seniors 50+ years of age to come together on Monday mornings to enjoy good company and activities. Activities may include Wii bowling, puzzles, pool, cards, and conversation.
name: Everson Senior Center

application_process: Participants join GRACE through community partner referrals.
description: A community-based effort to find solutions for individuals who are high utilizers of emergency and criminal justice systems. The aim is to offer intensive, coordinated services to those whose needs span beyond any single agency. The GRACE Program provides intensive case management, coordination of services, and ongoing support.
name: Ground-Level Response and Coordinated Engagement (GRACE)

description: Provides limited emergency financial assistance through vouchers for food, gas, and other basic needs. Call  and leave a message to request assistance. Messages will be responded to on Tuesday mornings
name: St. Vincent de Paul Society

description: If you need access to the Internet, your Library can help by lending you a mobile Wi-Fi hotspot device. If you have a Bellingham or Whatcom County library card, you may borrow a hotspot for 3 weeks. If no one is waiting, it can be renewed up to 3 times. Visit the online catalog to place a request.
name: WiFi Hotspot Lending - BPL

description: Support for family members to find the appropriate help for individuals experiencing Chemical Dependency (drug addiction or alcoholism). If you have a loved one, an employee or friend who is struggling with substance abuse, call to set up a consultation.
name: Intervention Services - Contact Counseling

description: Dial 2-1-1 from anywhere in Washington State to get connected to local services.
name: Washington 211

description: Programs include hiking and walking groups, fitness classes, health services, writing and discussion groups, artistic opportunities, card games, music and dance, recreation, senior community meals, and more.
name: Bellingham Senior Activity Center

description: Veterans with a legal problem related to housing may talk to a lawyer for free. Call for more information.
name: Veteran Advocacy

description: A peer-support meeting for parents and caregivers who identify as LGBTQIA+, and with children aged 0-12. Groups will meet virtually once a week for 12 weeks.
fees: Sliding scale, flexible pricing. Call for details.
name: PEPS LGBTQIA+ Program

description: Families needing information and education specifically related to Down syndrome are provided a trained Parent Advocate to address their needs. Families are also connected to other families to develop natural peer support through fun, family-friendly events throughout the year.
name: Down Syndrome Outreach Program

description: As a HUD-certified agency, Clearpoint offers housing programs that can help with a variety of situations, from buying your first house to helping you retain your home in times of crisis.
name: Housing Programs - Clearpoint

description: A fellowship of people that come together for help because a loved one’s drinking is affecting them. Loved ones can include spouses, siblings, children or grandchildren, parents or grandparents, and friends. Find a meeting close to you using the online search tool.
name: Al-Anon

application_process: Call to set an appointment, then an application will be mailed to you.
description: The Spring shoe distribution is scheduled for March / May, and Back to School Shoe Give is scheduled for August / September each year. An appointment must be scheduled in order to receive an application.
name: Blue Skies Shoe Distribution Program

application_process: Check website for application details.
description: 5-week summer day program for elementary school-age children who have experienced difficult life circumstances and exhibit emotional and behavioral issues as a result, preventing them from assimilating into more traditional summer camps. Camp includes outdoor recreational and physical fitness-related activities, music and arts enrichment, daily off-site field trips, and small group conversations that encourage and support positive coping skills and self-management.
name: Ray of Hope Summer Day Camp

description: Six hours of continuing education are required to fulfill parental obligations in receiving Medicaid Personal Care funding to care for their family member. Twice a year the Parent Coalition Program conducts trainings tailored to meet the needs of these families. Email admin@arcwhatcom.org for more information.
name: Medicaid Personal Care Parent Training

description: Services include certified behavioral health and chemical dependency treatment, outpatient treatment and medication management, jail transition services, behavioral health case management, individual therapy, and specialty groups.
name: Sunrise Behavioral Health Services

application_process: Screenings can be completed for any child, birth to age five, whose family or caregiver would like more information about their child’s development. Call, email, or fill out the online form to apply.
description: A screening to identify any factors that may interfere with a child’s learning, growth and development. The screening is also provided to help parents identify their child’s strengths and weaknesses and provide home suggestions and/or further evaluation if needed in any area of concern. Any child, birth to five, whose family or care givers would like more information about their child’s development can contact their local school district to receive a free Child Find Screening.
name: Child Find Preschool Screenings - BPS

application_process: Register online or call.
description: 6-week education program for parents and family caregivers of children and teens whom are experiencing symptoms of a mental illness or whom have already been diagnosed.
name: NAMI Basics Class

application_process: Enrollment for Christmas assistance typically begins in October each year.
description: Holiday assistance programs that provide lower-income families in our community with an opportunity to receive gifts, have gifts for their children, and funds to purchase food for a Christmas dinner celebration.
name: Salvation Army Christmas Assistance

application_process: Call or complete an online request
description: Connects families with mental health providers who accept new patients, work with your insurance and fit your child’s treatment needs. The Referral Service is accessible to children and teens 17 and under living in Washington state. Teens between the ages of 13 and 17 can also call the Referral Service to find providers for themselves. For interpretation services, call 866-583-1527.
name: Washington’s Mental Health Referral Service for Children and Teens

application_process: Call or email if you have a child age 3 - 5 who you suspect may have a disability concern.
description: An Integrated Preschool Program that provides Mandated Preschool Services for children who are 3 to 5 years of age who have been identified as having developmental delays and/or disabilities, as well as developmentally appropriate preschool experience for a selected number of typical peers.
fees: Tuition only applies to peer students
name: Blaine Primary Developmental Preschool

description: Offers free one-to-one tutoring services for adults who wish to improve their literacy skills.Services include support for basic reading and writing skills, GED (General Educational Development) test preparation, and basic computer skills.
name: Adult Literacy Program - WLC

application_process: Schedule a time to connect with your peer supporter of choice on theEMBERCenter's website.
description: One-on-one parenting support with a peer provider of your choice. Schedule sessions via text, phone, or video chat as often as you want. Each session is about 30 minutes. Peer support providers are available in English and Spanish.
name: The EMBERcenter- Peer Support

description: Provides do-it-yourself court forms on a variety of non-criminal legal issues.
name: Washington Forms Online

description: Provides assistance to seniors and people with disabilities in need of state-funded care services.
name: Aging and Long-Term Support Administration

description: Bellingham Public Library works collaboratively with local educators to provide useful resources to Bellingham students, including curriculum support materials, and class visits for pre-school through high school students.
name: Teacher Resources - BPL

description: A mental health or addictions specialist is available to diagnose DSM5 disorders, make recommendations and referrals for treatment, and prepare court approved documentation.
name: Court Approved Evaluations - Clarity MHR

description: An ambulatory clinic that provides on-site, acute and preventive health care to the Nooksack Indian Tribe and eligible members of federally recognized Tribes. Services include family medicine, pediatric, obstetrics and gynecology, family planning, women’s health, diabetes screening and testing, nutrition education, and community health and nurse health care practices.
name: Nooksack Tribal Clinic

schedules.description:
Closed for lunch 12:00 - 1:00 PM. 
Closed on all recognized holidays.

description: A student loan counseling session will give you the opportunity to discuss your options with a counselor who will give personalized recommendations about the repayment programs you might qualify for, along with other suggestions to make the debt more manageable.
name: Student Loan Counseling - Clearpoint

application_process: Call or email for information
description: Provides counseling services for individuals, couples, and families. Case management services available for qualified Group Health clients in their homes or care facilities. Referrals to other care providers in the community provided when appropriate.
fees: Call for details and to confirm insurance benefits
name: Northwest Behavioral

description: Improves a home’s energy efficiency, durability, indoor air quality and addresses health and safety concerns.  Weatherization services focus on attic, floor and wall insulation, reducing drafts, heating system cleaning and safety inspection and ventilation improvements. Available for both homeowners and renters with landlord permission.
name: Weatherization Program

application_process: To request a grief companion for yourself or a loved one, fill out the online form
description: Those who have lost someone to suicide can receive phone-based peer support from someone who has also experienced a suicide loss.
name: Washington Survivors of Suicide Companion Mentor

application_process: Call to apply for services. There is a waitlist for services, wait times vary by service type.
description: Pediatric physical therapists are movement specialists who work with children with a wide range of diagnoses from infancy through adolescence. They help children work towards functioning independently and promote participation in various activities at home, school, and the community.
name: Kids in Motion Physical Therapy

application_process: Call or apply online
description: Meet with a parenting coach to achieve the unique goals you have for you, your teen and family.
fees: Fees apply. Insurance and private payment accepted, scholarships available.
name: Coaching for Parents with Teens - Parenting Academy

description: Free hot meal served weekly.
name: Loaves and Fishes Community Meal

application_process: Text "LGBTQ2S" to 94449 or "ALLY" to 94449, or sign up on their webpage.
description: The Paths (Re)Membered Project centers the Two Spirit and LGBTQ+ community provide a texting service for youth to provide support for LGBTQ+ Native youth.
fees: No fees. Standard text messaging rates may apply.
name: 2SLGBTQ+ Text

description: Assists individuals with serious and complex health care challenges to navigate large health care systems and find the resources they need to meet their health goals.
fees: Medicaid pays for Health Homes Care Coordination if you are eligible. Hospital Care Coordinators work with whomever is referred to them by the hospital social workers.
name: Care Coordination - NWRC

description: Find a support center or camp near you using the National Alliance for Children's Grief's online search tool.
name: Grief Support Center Search Tool

application_process: Contact an eligible vendor and ask for "intake" to set up an account.
description: If your child is on Apple Health medical, has special health care needs, and is 3 years or older, you can use the Apple Health Provider One medical to buy diapers from eligible vendors. Limit 200 diapers per month. See link for more details.
name: Apple Health Diaper Program

description: Offers transfer degrees, professional-technical training programs, as well as basic education, job skills, and Community & Continuing Education classes.
name: Whatcom Community College

description: Assists law enforcement agencies and parents in locating missing persons. Call the toll-free, 24-hour number to report missing persons. Local law enforcement must be notified before MUPU can become involved.
name: Missing & Unidentified Persons Unit

description: Services provided onsite include job search assistance, resume, cover letter, and interview assistance, clothing, housewares, bedding, food, shower passes, bus passes, internet, fax and phone access, and connections to basic need and educational resources in Whatcom County.
name: Ferndale Resource Center

description: Providers work closely with Veterans to plan for all the care they need to stay healthy and well throughout life, including immunizations and vaccinations.
name: VA Primary Care

description: WIC is a supplemental food and nutrition/breastfeeding education program that helps pregnant women, new mothers and young children eat well, learn about nutrition and breastfeeding, and stay healthy.
name: Lummi WIC

description: Programs for people with developmental disabilities, including services for personal care, respite, employment, residential supports, and more.
name: Developmental Disabilities Administration

description: Respite care allows foster parents to get trusted and trauma informed care for the kids that they care for, while they get some time off.
name: Skookum Kids Respite

description: Report concerns involving vulnerable adults online, by phone, fax, or email.
name: Adult Protective Services

description: Advocacy counseling is available to clients who want to meet one-on-one with an advocacy counselor. Sessions are available on a walk-in or scheduled basis during business hours. These sessions are strength and empowerment-based and include emotional support, on-going safety planning, identifying coping skills, problem solving, information about the effects of domestic violence and sexual assault, and referrals to other community resources.
name: DVSAS Advocacy Counseling

application_process: Drop in, no registration required.
description: A peer support group for Spanish speaking mothers. Meets twice a month, both in-person and zoom options available.
name: Círculo de Alianza Latina para la Maternidad Acompañada

application_process: Applications available online and must be submitted via mail. Main funding available 4 times a year. Scholarship specific funding available once a year.
description: Grants for children and young adults with medical problems or physical disabilities to meet needs that are not covered by insurance. Also provides education scholarships to young adults with medical and/or physical disabilities.
name: Sisu Children's Fund

application_process: Call to notify Social Security Administration immediately when a person dies.
description: Benefits paid to widows, widowers, and dependents of eligible workers. This benefit is particularly important for young families with children. You and your family could be eligible for benefits based on the earnings of a worker who died. The deceased person must have worked long enough to qualify for benefits.
name: Social Security Survivors Benefits

description: Services ensure Tribal Veterans receive the benefits they deserve for serving their country.
name: Nooksack Tribal Veterans Program

alternate_name: Coordinated Legal Education, Advice and Referral
description: A toll-free legal hotline for people with low incomes. Services are targeted to problems that affect basic needs such as housing, income, medical care and family safety. Due to limited resources, lawyers and paralegals are not able to assist every caller.
name: CLEAR Hotline

description: Trainings for local businesses, organizations, and service providers on domestic violence and sexual assault. These trainings are focused on a wide variety of topics, including sexual harassment in the workplace, medical provider trainings, working with victims of violence, and responding to children and teens who have experienced violence.
name: DVSAS Professional Trainings

application_process: Complete a Child Find Screening to find out if your child qualifies.
description: Provides a developmentally appropriate curriculum for children 3 -  5 years old who have significant developmental delays.
name: Developmental Preschool - FSD

application_process: Call outpatient assessment line for a referral.
description: Counseling and support services to families with children and youth who may have emotional and/or behavioral challenges. Services include individual therapy, family therapy, and group therapy, case management services to coordinate with schools, Children’s Administration, juvenile justice and other systems that are involved with the particular client.
name: Compass Health Child and Family Outpatient Services

description: Staffing experts put people to work in a wide variety of industries. Job placements available to help you earn more money, develop new skills and build relationships with potential employers.
name: PeopleReady Job Placement

description: Serves students experiencing homelessness. This program is designed to reduce isolation, maximize stability and maintain consistency for this population of children and youth. Contact the liaison in your school district for support.
name: McKinney-Vento Program - LNS

application_process: Register online.
description: A structured recovery support group that offers respect, encouragement, and hope. Free to those living with mental illness, this group promotes connection and understanding while respecting confidentiality.
name: NAMI Connection Recovery Support Group

schedules.description: Meetings take place online every Tuesday of the month (excluding major holidays). The 4th Tuesday meets in-person at NAMI Whatcom Office.

description: Provides nursing and other jail health program administrative services in both facilities under contract with Whatcom County Jail and the Work Center. NWRC jail health staff coordinate closely with other medical providers and behavioral health staff to provide quality healthcare.
name: Jail Health - NWRC

application_process: Download application online.
description: A program that supports expenses related to helping foster youth graduate high school and/or enroll in higher education (dependent on funding availability). This program is open but not limited to those living in traditional foster homes, group homes, residential treatment centers, kinship care, independent living programs, and emergency placement centers. See application for eligible expenses.
name: Foster Grads Program

application_process: Information and questions about the application process, criteria and waiting list should be directed to the individual program director/staff of properties of interest.
description: Housing programs serve low-income individuals, families, seniors, and persons with special physical and mental needs, offering resident support services in addition to a clean and safe place to live.
name: Catholic Housing Services

application_process: Download application online.
description: Scholarship offered to teens ages 15 to 17 who are homeless, low-income, or in foster care. Application, essay, parent/guardian letter of reference, a third party letter of reference, school grades transcript, and access to a car and auto insurance required. Typically, the scholarship grants up to $400 toward driver's education and is limited to a certain number of scholarships available each Spring and Fall. Award is based on both merit and need.​
name: Blue Skies Driver's Education Scholarship

description: Library of free "know your rights" articles, videos, court forms and do-it-yourself packets covering many common legal issues such as family law, eviction/housing, public benefits and money/debt problems.
name: Washington Law Help

application_process: Fill out the Intake Paperwork available online, return paperwork to Lake Whatcom Center.
description: A co-occurring 32-bed facility providing 24/7 clinical support for individuals diagnosed with persistent mental illness and substance use challenges. Provides psychiatric, MAT, and counseling services through an integrated approach facilitated by qualified professionals.
name: Residential Treatment - LWC

application_process: Apply online in November.
description: The Holiday Giving Store is set up just like a store, but gifts are free to families that qualify. The store is stocked with a variety of gifts and toys, and warm clothing like pajamas and sweatshirts are available for parents or guardians to choose for each child. Application typically opens in November.
name: Ferndale Holiday Giving Store

description: Food bank distribution the first Saturday and third Friday of every month.
name: Foothills Food Bank Mobile Food Pantry

description: Teen volunteers are trained to listen to concerns and talk about a variety of issues, including bullying, drug and alcohol concerns, relationships, stress, and depression. Calls and chats are confidential.
name: Teen Link

description: View online resources or call the Family Center for help finding the right program to help your family pay for child care.
name: Help Pay for Child Care

description: Provides support for those in need of help overcoming a reliance on prescription pain medication, heroin, or alcohol.
name: Medication Assisted Recovery (MAR) - Lifeline Connections

application_process: Fill out an intake form, fill out a budget and submit additional documentation. Call or email to begin intake process.
description: Housing and Urban Development (HUD)-Approved Housing Counseling Agency. Offers free pre-purchase homebuyer education and financial counseling to anyone in the community.
name: Housing Counseling - Kulshan Community Land Trust

description: A parent-child program for children ages 18 months to 3 years, with and without special needs. Check online for registration openings.
name: Sensational Toddlers

description: Help with psychiatric medication management for a variety of psychiatric conditions.
name: Psych Med Management - Clarity MHR

description: Investigates the extent to which individuals with disabilities retain their basic rights to make personal and financial decisions and how people in positions to assist them in exercising those rights respect, protect, and facilitate the individual’s expressed interests.
name: Rights Investigation and Accountability

application_process: Apply online, by mail, or through a phone or internet company.
description: A federal program dedicated to making phone and internet service more affordable for low-income households. This benefit provides eligible consumers with a monthly discount of up to $9.25, or up to $34.25 per month for households living on on qualifying Tribal land. Certain Lifeline providers offer free phone service for qualifying households, and may provide you with a free phone.
name: Lifeline
service_at_locations: Help Pay for Internet or Phone

description: Washington’s Safe Medication Return lets people dispose of household over-the-counter, and prescription medications (including medications for household pets). Visit the website or call the hotline for information on how to safely dispose of medication.
name: Safe Medication Return

description: A screening to identify any factors that may interfere with a child’s learning, growth and development. The screening is also provided to help parents identify their child’s strengths and weaknesses and provide home suggestions and/or further evaluation if needed in any area of concern. Any child, birth to five, whose family or care givers would like more information about their child’s development can contact their local school district to receive a free Child Find Screening.
name: Child Find Screenings - MBSD

description: An opportunity for members to have a fun weekend with friends while having a night on the town. Activities include Art Walk, evening strolls, in-house games and activities, and a fun place to hang out with friends.
name: Max Higbee Weekend Program

application_process: Contact to apply.
description: A supportive environment for children and adults to process their grief. Each child is able to work through their grief at their own pace, engaging with the various “play stations” as they see fit, while their parent or caregiver has the option of meeting with their own support group.
name: Our Treehouse Family Night

description: Provides direct representation to immigrant survivors of violence seeking immigration benefits. While the VAWA Unit handles several hundred immigration cases per year, the demand for assistance continues to be greater than the available resources meaning there is a long waitlist for clients seeking help.
name: Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) Unit

description: Offerings include lap swims, American Red Cross swim lessons and training courses, shallow water aerobics, deep water running, as well as preschool swims and open swims for people to play and enjoy the facility.
fees: Day passes, 10 visit passes, 3 month passes, and annual passes available for a fee.
name: Arne Hanna Aquatic Center

application_process: Text "Sex" to 94449, or sign up on their webpage.
description: Tips and resources about sex and relationships for Native youth. Get everything you need to know about sex and relationships delivered privately to your phone.
fees: No fees. Standard text messaging rates may apply.
name: Text 4 Sex Ed

description: The women’s health specialists at PeaceHealth help manage the body’s changing needs through all of life’s stages. Team members may include gynecologists, obstetricians, nurse practitioners, certified mid-wives, pelvic floor specialists or gynecologic surgeons. Conditions treated include benign (noncancerous) gynecologic conditions, bladder or bowel leakage, gynecological cancer, and pelvic problems.
name: PeaceHealth Women's Health

description: The Whatcom County Health Department partners with community organizations and all seven Whatcom County school districts to coordinate and support prevention coalitions and community groups. These coalitions work with schools and others to increase connections and support healthy youth and families. Visit the website to learn more and get involved.
name: Prevention Coalitions

description: Adaptable trainings, educational presentations, and informational outreach for communities and the groups that live and work within them. Contact DSNW for more information.
name: Dementia Support NW Training, Education, and Outreach

description: License up to three pets using the online form.
name: Pet Licensing - WHS

application_process: Visit the website or call for details.
description: Therapy services for individual adults, children and adolescents, couples, families and groups.
name: Bayside Therapy Counseling

description: Around-the-clock care for serious illnesses and injuries. Conditions treated include behavioral health emergencies, brain & spine trauma, cerebrovascular emergencies, heart emergencies, orthopedic injuries, overdoses or poisonings, pregnancy complications, respiratory emergencies, and traumatic injuries.
name: PeaceHealth Emergency Medicine

description: Call your local branch to arrange document printing and pick up, or submit a request online. Library patrons are provided a $7.00 printing credit each week. Beyond that, printing fees are $0.10 (black & white) or $0.50 (color) per page.
name: WCLS Printing Services

application_process: You can apply for Basic Food Assistance online at washingtonconnection.org, by phone, or at your local Community Services Office.
description: The Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, or SNAP, called Basic Food in Washington, helps people with low incomes make ends meet by providing monthly benefits to buy food. Apply online at washingtonconnection.org, by phone, or at your local Community Services Office.
name: Basic Food (SNAP)

description: Training for service providers who may serve the immigrant community as part of their work. These sessions answer questions that community members may have about the immigration system, immigration enforcement, and how immigration issues affect the communities they serve. Training includes an overview of the immigration system and immigration status as well as which resources are available in the community.
name: Immigration 101 Training for Service Providers

application_process: Fill out the "Get Help" form online to request assistance.
description: There are two primary ways to receive help: request volunteers to help with simple work, or submit a request for help/financial assistance which will be shared with church partners. There are no guarantees for assistance, and it can take some time (often 3-8 weeks) to arrange. Fill out the "Get Help" form online to request assistance.
name: Love INC

application_process: Must become a Washington Autism Alliance member to access services. Membership is free and can be completed online.
description: Provides a range of advocacy services to help adults, youth, and children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and other developmental disabilities gain access to health and educational services and supports. These services include family resource and insurance navigation, and legal advocacy on issues related to access to healthcare and education.
name: Advocacy and Legal Services - WA Autism Alliance

application_process: Call for details
description: Mental health assessments are provided to all child victims of abuse.
name: Mental Health Assessments - Dawson Place

description: Relevant local mental health related information gathered from the community and shared through a periodic electronic newsletter.
name: Whatcom Mental Health Newsletter

description: Provides food to Blaine, Custer, Birch Bay, and Semiahmoo residents. Fresh fruits and vegetables, dairy, protein, and bakery items offered in an "outdoor undercover farmers market" setting.
name: Blaine Food Bank

application_process: Call to speak with a case manager
description: A 2-3 hour long mediation process for parents/guardians and teens to resolve conflicts.
name: Parent/Teen Mediation

description: Free one-on-one financial coaching for people with disabilities in Washington and Oregon. Topics include credit, savings, debt, budgeting, banking, identity protection, benefits, and assistive technology.
name: NWAF Financial Coaching

description: Housed at the Opportunity Council, this program provides resources and support for families and medical professionals looking for services for children birth to 21 in Whatcom County with known or suspected special health care needs.
name: Single Entry Access to Services

description: Anonymous and confidential help line that provides crisis intervention and referral services for Washington State residents. Professionally trained volunteers and staﬀ are available to provide emotional support 24 hours a day, and oﬀer local treatment resources for substance abuse, problem gambling and mental health as well as to other community services.
name: Washington Recovery Help Line

description: Help for people with dementia and their caregivers. Can provide support and make referrals to individuals experiencing dementia including for memory screening, medical diagnosis, and support groups; support to caregivers of people with dementia of all levels, including consultation, options counseling, care planning, and appropriate referrals; dementia education; legal resources; social opportunities; and more.
name: Dementia Support Program - NWRC

description: Services include meal program, wellness programs, exercise and rehabilitation opportunities, recreational center, educational center, entertainment, social space, and information and assistance.
name: Lynden Community / Senior Center

application_process: Call phone number and press 1 to be connected to the Referral Line to be assigned an advocate. Responses may take up to 48-hours during business hours only.
description: Criminal justice system advocacy, resources, referrals, educational and support groups for victims of crime and their families. Services are free of charge.  Please note that VSS is located in Washington State and serves Snohomish county with limited services in other WA counties (King, Island, Skagit and Whatcom) on a case-by-case basis.
name: Victim Support Services

phones.description: Press 1 to be connected to the Referral Line.

application_process: Registration is first-come, first- served and is limited to one week per child/family. Complete a participant registration form available online, and return by mail or email to program@animalsasnaturaltherapy.org.
description: Summer camp for youth ages 6-18. Get to know horses, create fun art projects, play with cute farm animals, meet new friends, develop valuable life skills, and more. Day Camp is not a horseback riding camp – while there is some riding involved, it is only a part of what is done while at camp.
fees: Fees apply. Partial scholarships are available based on a sliding fee scale. Proof of income and Financial Aid Application is required.
name: Summer Day Camp - ANT

description:
Individual, couples, and family counseling available. Individual counseling sessions are designed to address a client’s specific recovery and/or mental health needs. Sessions may focus on trauma, sadness, grief, stress, loneliness and other factors leading to a cycle of addiction. Each patient is encouraged to have some couples or family counseling as well. 

Family therapy can be done with or without the primary client present.
name: Substance Use Disorder Counseling - Clarity MHR

application_process: Wait list opens the first school day in the January prior to the desired school year
description: Serves children ages 3 through 5 who have a disability as well as students who do not have a disability (peer models).  Students who qualify for Special Education services are enrolled and served as they turn 3 years of age. Children who do not qualify for Special Education services but who are ages 3 to 5 may apply to be enrolled.
fees: Tuition only applies for children who do not qualify for Special Education services
name: Lynden Inclusive Preschool

description: Helps cover the cost of prescription drugs. You can join a Medicare drug plan in addition to Original Medicare (Parts A and B), or you get it by joining a Medicare Advantage Plan with drug coverage (Part C). Plans that offer Medicare drug coverage are run by private insurance companies that follow rules set by Medicare.
name: Medicare Part D (Drug Coverage)

description: Virtual gathering series open to mothers, adoptive mothers, and non-gestational mothers with children aged 0-5 years, working outside of the home. 8-week series of 1.5 hour meetings held on weekday evenings or weekday lunchtimes.
name: PEPS Working Moms Program

application_process: Apply by mail. Once an application is received, applicants will be notified within 14 days that it is either complete, or incomplete indicating what documents are missing. Application decision process may take up to 45 days.
description: Provides funds to families in need to help cover costs associated with medical bills, therapies and numerous other aspects of supporting a child or young adult on the autism spectrum. Applicants request a yearly grant to help cover the costs to get the care, support and items needed.
name: Ben's Fund

description: A Debt Management Program is a structured repayment plan that helps you pay off your unsecured debts more easily. Often, it comes with the added benefits of lower interest rates and waived fees.
name: Debt Management Program (DMP) - Clearpoint

description: A program for young adults ages 16 to 30 with developmental disabilities. Self advocacy members are encouraged to develop and practice skills to become strong self-advocates.
name: Self-Advocacy Program

description: Provides emotional support and information to families of children with developmental disabilities, delays, and ongoing health care needs
name: Parent to Parent Support Programs

description: 24-hour services include picking up stray, injured, aggressive, dangerous and dead animals; transportation and impoundment of stray animals to the shelter for impound, or in cases of emergency, to a veterinarian for medical treatment; and more. If you are aware of an animal being abused or neglected, please call the Animal Control Office.
name: Animal Control and Rescue Services - WHS

description: A variety of dispute resolution trainings are available, including Mediation Trainings (Professional, Family, and Parent-Teen offerings), Parent Education Trainings, Conflict Resolution Trainings, and Exploring Equity and Cultural Humility.
name: WDRC Trainings

description: Counseling for drug and alcohol abuse, low self-esteem, bullying, eating disorders, uncontrolled anger, self-injury or suicidal ideation, academic underachievement, and family issues.
fees: All insurance providers accepted, sliding scale available if no insurance.
name: Child and Adolescent Counseling - TouchStone

application_process: Call to reach a crisis counselor.
description: Connect to a crisis counselor 24/7, 365 days a year, from anywhere in the U.S.
name: Crisis Helpline- The Trevor Project

description: Faith-based organization with free services including pregnancy tests, limited ultrasound, options education, STI testing, parenting and childbirth education, and support groups.
name: Whatcom County Pregnancy Clinic

description: WA State certified DVIT provider. Intimate partner violence is addressed through programs that are mandated by the court, but provide a safe and nurturing place to grow and learn. Services include Domestic Violence Assessments, support group, and individual counseling.
name: Domestic Violence Intervention Treatment (DVIT)

description: Provides quality educational opportunities from early childhood through life, in accordance with the Tribe’s need for cultural and economic well-being in keeping with the wide diversity of the Tribe as distinct cultural and governmental entities. Services include education grants, student support for struggling students, and a Tribal Education Liaison to assist Nooksack families communicate with local school districts.
name: Nooksack Education Department

description: Temporary workforce hiring and professional recruiting solutions.  Industries include construction, light industrial, healthcare, hospitality, CDL/non-CDL, disaster restoration, and more.
name: HireQuest

description: Defends the rights of people who have a fear of persecution in their home country and help them gain safety through asylum. Also assists 'pro se' applicants with navigating the asylum application process, and works with outside agencies, communities, and organizations to promote the rights and dignity of and offer support services to persons fleeing persecution in their home countries.
name: Asylum Unit - NWIRP

description: Immediate, free and expert treatment advice and assistance provided by phone 24/7/365.
name: Poison Center Hotline

description: Serves students experiencing homelessness. This program is designed to reduce isolation, maximize stability and maintain consistency for this population of children and youth. Contact the liaison in your school district for support.
name: McKinney-Vento Program - MBSD

application_process: Call or email for details, or online referral form available.
description: Family Companions offer support to parents during a time of need. A Family Companion is a volunteer who wants to share an unconditional relationship with a parent in their community.
name: Family Companions Program - PREPARES

description: Provides job seekers access to jobs, personal guidance, and career development including assessments, training, and education programs.
name: Manpower Job Placement

application_process: Register online.
description: Support group for family members, parents, caregivers, and friends of individuals struggling with mental illness.
name: NAMI Family Support Group

schedules.description: Wednesday meeting takes place online weekly.
Monday meeting takes place weekly in-person at NAMI Whatcom Office.

application_process: Apply online or in person.
description: Apply online or in person to receive a free library card. Adult applicants will ned to provide a photo ID.
name: Library Cards - BPL

description: Provides coordination and recovery services to individuals, families and entities adversely impacted by disaster in Whatcom County.
name: Whatcom Long Term Recovery Group

description: A screening to identify any factors that may interfere with a child’s learning, growth and development. The screening is also provided to help parents identify their child’s strengths and weaknesses and provide home suggestions and/or further evaluation if needed in any area of concern. Any child, birth to five, whose family or care givers would like more information about their child’s development can contact their local school district to receive a free Child Find Screening.
name: Child Find Screenings - NVSD

application_process: Download an application online. Return by email, or mail to AWGFLC PO Box 218, Everson, WA 98247.
description: Children of adult learners grow in their reading, writing and math skills while attending the Making SMILIES Learning Pathways class.
name: Making SMILIES Learning Pathways Class

description: Need help with technology questions or with using the Library’s electronic resources? Help is available by phone, by email, in person, or with one-on-one assistance during a Tech Basics Coaching session. Coaching sessions take place every Wednesday afternoon at the Central Library. Check the event calendar for upcoming sessions, and call to register.
name: Tech Help - BPL

application_process: Contact for more information.
description: Rebound acts as a collaborative bridge between state agencies, schools, community-based services, the legal system, and churches. The Family Advocacy Support program strengthens connections with each family participating in programs by providing a single access point between Rebound and other social services. Services include one-on-one mentorship, referrals to additional services, and help for families to network with other families struggling with similar challenges.
name: Family Advocacy Support

description: By calling 1-800-RUNAWAY, you can connect with a trusted, compassionate person who will listen and help you create a plan to address your concerns. Live Chat online and email also available.
name: 1-800-Runaway Hotline

description: Provides linguistically and culturally appropriate health care services and health information to the farmworker community. During high migrant season, services include mobile medical and dental clinics at farms, farmworker camps and housing sites, and summer health fairs. During off-peak season, services include culturally-appropriate workshops, and presentations and events to farms, housing sites and gathering spaces on critical health topics.
name: Sea Mar Migrant and Seasonal Farmworker Promotores Program

application_process: Contact Blaine Food Bank for more information.
description: Home delivery provided once a week for anyone who needs food but is unable to visit the Blaine Food Bank in person. Call or email for more information.
name: Blaine Food Bank Home Delivery Program

application_process: Use the doctor locator online to find a provider near you, then contact the provider to schedule an assessment.
description: A public health program designed to ensure that eye and vision care becomes an integral part of infant wellness care to improve a child's quality of life. Under this program, no-cost comprehensive eye and vision assessments are available for infants 6-12 months old regardless of a family's income or access to insurance coverage.
name: InfantSEE Assessment

description: Services include individualized treatment plans, DUI and chemical dependency assessments, outpatient services, intensive outpatient services, alcohol and drug information school, individual and group therapy, help with family and personal conflicts, and connection with legal, employment, and family services.
name: Sunrise Recovery Services

description: Confidentially ask for support online. The Ask an Advocate page is monitored Monday-Friday, 9am - 5pm. You should receive a message back within 24-hours. If you need to speak with someone immediately, please call the helpline.
name: Ask an Advocate at DVSAS

description: Senior programming has been on hold since 2020 due to COVID-19. Offers a variety of activities and programs to meet the diverse interests of the local senior population. Activities include:
name: Welcome Senior Activity Center

description: Mediation, conflict coaching, and phone conciliation services for landlords and tenants who wish to resolve disputes, improve communication, increase understanding, successfully negotiate payment or re-payment plans, discuss deposits and move out timelines, address lease agreements and other related issues, and move forward with creative solutions determined by the parties.
name: Landlord-Tenant Mediation

description: In an effort to ensure that all children have access to food during the weekend the Blaine Food Bank is proud to partner with Wild Bird Charity and the Blaine School District to provide the food for three meals a day, as well as snacks, each weekend for children in the Blaine community who face hunger. Call or email for more information.
name: Blaine Food Bank Weekend Backpack Program

application_process: Request an interpreter online.
description: Provides interpreting for the deaf and hard of hearing, for all events, occasions, and engagements. Interpreting services include American Sign Language (ASL), Signed English (PSE) transliteration, Signed Exact English (SEE), tactile and close visual interpretation for deafblind individuals, oral translation for deaf or hard of hearing individuals who rely on speechreading, and Lip-Reading Translation (LRT) for individuals who are unable to express themselves vocally due to tracheotomy or other physical disability.
name: HSDC Interpreting Services

description: Members engage in a variety of activities and community excursions. Programs include YMCA workouts, cooking classes, hikes, sports, library visits, art projects and much more. Alternative activities are always provided.
name: Max Higbee Weekday Program

description: Provides a variety of substance use disorder services. These include drug and alcohol use assessments, intervention, consultation and addiction treatment referral services.
name: Drug and Alcohol Counseling - Contact Counseling

description: A community refrigerator packed with free nutritious food that breaks down barriers to food access. Expect to find the Freedge packed Tuesday – Saturday with individual portions of surplus food from local restaurants, garden produce, and shelf stable pantry items. The freedge is located behind the RE Store near the RE Patch Community Garden.
name: Freedge Food Pantry

application_process: Referrals are made through school district staff in the Fall. Contact your district for more information.
description: Provides new school clothing and shoes to students in need in K through 12 grades. Referrals made through Whatcom County School Districts in the fall. Teen Team program, operating under Operation School Bell, is a voucher program for homeless high school students identified by the homeless high school coordinators.
name: Operation School Bell

description: Coordinated primary medical and dental care for children and adolescents, including well-child visits, newborn care, developmental screenings, immunizations, sports exams, and specialty referrals.
fees: Apple Health (Medicaid), Medicare, and private insurance accepted. Sliding Fee Discount Program available based on household size and income.
name: Unity Care NW Children's Medical Care

application_process: Text "Native" to begin.
description: Crisis text line for Native youth when experiencing crisis. Confidential, available 24/7, no cost.
fees: No fees. Standard text messaging rates may apply.
name: Native Crisis Text Line

application_process: Online application available
description: Empowers youth to approach conflict in healthy and creative ways through a restorative justice approach.
name: Youth Restorative Practices Program

description: This program is designed for families in their third trimester of pregnancy, or who are planning to adopt a baby within the next few months. Local expectant and adoptive parents can attend this 6-week, 1.5 hours weekly online program, solo or with a partner. It is recommended for families to register for a group that best aligns with their baby's due date.
fees: Sliding scale, flexible pricing. Call for details.
name: Connecting the Expecting Program

application_process: Call ahead to schedule food pick-up. Locations and phone numbers available online.
description: Community-based food distributor with locations throughout Whatcom County. Food pick-up days/times vary by location. Schedule and phone numbers for each location are listed online.
name: Miracle Food Network

application_process: Download an application online. Return by email, or mail to AWGFLC PO Box 218, Everson, WA 98247.
description: Non-native English speakers are empowered with tools they can use as members of a growing community through classes for adults in ESL/ELL and Certified Education in Spanish.
name: ESL/ELL Classes - A Watered Garden

description: A Medicare-approved plan from a private company that offers an alternative to Original Medicare for your health and drug coverage. These “bundled” plans include Part A, Part B, and usually Part D. Plans may have lower out-of-pocket costs than Original Medicare, and may offer some extra benefits that Original Medicare doesn’t cover, like vision, hearing, and dental services.
name: Medicare Advantage (Part C)

application_process: You can apply for TANF online at washingtonconnection.org, by phone, or at your local Community Services Office.
description: Provides temporary cash assistance for families in need. Some families participate in the WorkFirst Program. The WorkFirst Program helps participants find and keep jobs.
name: Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF)

application_process: Reservations are required no later than 5:00 PM the day before you ride. Since seating is limited, calling a day (or up to a week) in advance is recommended.
description: Provides limited transit service to rural areas of Whatcom County. There are no eligibility requirements for using zone service; anyone within the designated area can request a ride. Service is only available to each zone on certain days of the week. Advance reservations are required.
name: WTA Zone Service

description: Serves Special Education, English Language Learners, Native American Education, Section 504, Early Learning and McKinney Vento (Homeless families and youth), students in Foster Care and Migrant students, student health needs and families and students in need of resources (clothing, food, transportation, etc.).
name: Ferndale Student Services

description: Transforms people and neighborhoods by providing a means for volunteers, nonprofits, schools, government and health care organizations to come together to solve community challenges.
name: Whatcom Volunteer Center

application_process: Download an application online. Return by email, or mail to AWGFLC PO Box 218, Everson, WA 98247.
description: General Education Diploma graduates will find themselves better qualified for employment advancements.
name: GED Class - A Watered Garden

description: Provides both in-home energy assessments and classroom-based workshops to identify ways to save on energy bills, conserve energy and water, improve health and safety in homes. This services is no cost to eligible households.
name: Conservation Education

application_process: Complete a Primary Eligibility Interest Form
description: A unique opportunity for hardworking families to help build and buy their own homes. Eligibility based on length of Whatcom residency, income, current housing status, ability to make timely monthly mortgage payments, and background check.
name: Habitat for Humanity Housing Help

application_process: Call the Crisis Care Line at 800-584-3578.
description: The Whatcom County Triage Center (WCTC) in Bellingham can accommodate 5 individuals who are recovering from a mental health crisis. Services include crisis stabilization, walk-in emergency, and next day appointments. Referrals can be made by calling the Crisis Care Line at 800-584-3578. Professionals can call directly to make referrals at 360-676-2020.
name: Crisis Triage and Stabilization

description: Diseases like HIV or hepatitis C can be spread when people who use injection drugs share needles or other equipment. Syringe clinics provide new, sterile needles and equipment to people who use injection drugs, and provide connections to drug treatment, disease testing, vaccines, and other social services.
name: Syringe Services Program

phones.description: Prevention and Screening Clinic, Communicable Disease, and Epidemiology Phone

application_process: Apply online
description: At each weekly appointment, clients will meet one-on-one with a trained peer mentor for one hour. With each lesson that is completed, clients will earn “baby bucks” for supplies such as diapers, wipes, clothing, blankets, and much more.
name: Earn While You Learn

description:
Pregnant individuals and parents of infants who have Apple Health/ Medicaid health insurance are eligible to receive: assistance applying for SNAP/ Basic Food benefits, Childcare Subsidy, and PFML benefits; 
nutritionist advice; help accessing medical and behavioral health care; and monthly gift cards for participating in Culturally Responsive Integrated & Strength-Based Parenting (CRISP) classes.
name: Maternity Support Services and Infant Case Management (Answers Counseling)

description: An online resource with information on programs that provide assistance to people who are unable to afford their medications and health care costs. All information is free, easy to access and updated regularly.
name: NeedyMeds

description: A state agency that investigates reports of child abuse and neglect.
name: Child Protective Services

description: Information, referrals, and assistance in obtaining services that support independence, dignity, and health of older adults and people with disabilities. Staff can assist with services including in-home care, Medicaid long term care coverage, caregiver support, long-term care options, and other general resources.
name: Aging and Disability Resources - NWRC

application_process: Email, call or drop-in for services.
description: Provides job search support, career exploration, computer use, training on resumes and cover letters, and interview preparation. Job training programs for youth, adults, and mature workers, as well as worker retraining.
name: WorkSource Whatcom

application_process: Download application online.
description: Provides curb-to-curb (and if needed, door-to-door) transportation to riders whose disability prevents them from riding fixed route bus system. ​Everyone who rides paratransit must qualify and be approved before riding. Read about paratransit eligibility online.
name: Paratransit

description: Helps cover inpatient care in hospitals, skilled nursing facility care, hospice care, and home health care. (Included in Original Medicare)
name: Medicare Part A (Hospital Insurance)

description: An online database of community resources to help in the event of emergencies and other difficult situations.
name: WCLS Community Resources

application_process: Select the "chat with us" option on The Trevor Project's website.
description: Connect to a crisis counselor 24/7, 365 days a year, from anywhere in the U.S.
name: Crisis Online Chat - The Trevor Project

description: Provides fresh and frozen produce, dairy products, meat, proteins, canned and dry goods, and bread. When available, items like baby food, vitamins, hygiene items, and vegetable starts also provided. Please bring your own bags or boxes. Pre-packed box delivery available for homebound individuals.
name: Foothills Food Bank

description: Inpatient treatment programs, as well as outpatient treatment programs designed to be as flexible as possible, allowing you to maintain your obligations while still seeking treatment.
name: Substance Use Disorder (SUD) Services - Lifeline Connections

application_process: Fill out registration form on website and email.
description: Support group where parents can work through their grief in an atmosphere of understanding and compassion. The non-denominational Support Group meets for eight consecutive weeks and includes a social worker, spiritual guidance counselor, and an interfaith minister.
name: Mending Babyloss Support Group

description: Free legal advice for low-income renters in Whatcom County. If you are worried about being evicted or have any questions regarding your rights as a tenant, call to see if you qualify and set an appointment. The Tenant Clinic is offered virtually by appointment, and once per month in person at Street Law.
name: Tenant Clinic

application_process: Online application available
description: Free and low cost workshops for youth (4th-12th grade) to gain skills in conflict resolution.
name: Youth Conflict Resolution Education

application_process: Application forms for specific animals can be submitted online or may be downloaded.
description: Interactive adoption process strives to place animals into permanent, responsible and loving homes. Prior to meeting an animal, potential adopters are asked to complete an adoption application to better help WHS staff understand what you are looking for in a companion animal.
name: Pet Adoption - WHS

application_process: Contact the Foothills Food Bank to set up delivery.
description: Homebound families and seniors can receive a pre-packed box or bag from the food bank every week delivered directly to their home. Contact the Foothills Food Bank to set up delivery.
name: Foothills Food Bank Home Delivery

application_process: Call or apply online
description: An intensive treatment program that works with parents and children together to improve the quality of the parent-child relationship and to teach parents the skills necessary to manage their child's severe behavior problems. Appropriate for children ages 2 to 7 with behavioral concerns.
fees: Fees apply. Insurance and private payment accepted.
name: Parent-Child Interaction Therapy - Parenting Academy

description: Advocacy opportunities that aim to ensure the needs of persons with developmental disabilities are met with appropriate health and social services.
name: The Arc Legislative Advocacy

description: A computer lab open at specific times for community members and Goodwill students to search for jobs, do homework, and practice computer skills.
name: Job Readiness Lab - Goodwill

description: If you are struggling to afford necessary home repairs or need help making modifications to your home due to changing mobility and ability needs related to aging, injury, or emerging disability, call the WHRC Hotline for help determining if there is a program in your area that would be a match for your needs.
name: Home Repair and Modification Assistance - WHRC

application_process: Call or email the Lifeline Connections Admissions office. Online form available.
description: A clinician works with you and your family (significant other and/or children) to promote healthy relationships, improve communication and improve the overall well-being of all individuals in the family.
name: Lifeline Connections Family Therapy

application_process: Fill out the online contact form or call to request information.
description: Provides residence, meals, medication management services, medical supervision, recreational activities and other supportive services to persons living with HIV/AIDS and who also may suffer from other diseases, mental illness, substance abuse, and/or developmental disabilities. To qualify for residency must have low or no income, diagnosis of HIV/AIDS, and be unable to live independently.
name: Sean Humphrey House

application_process: Register online or call.
description: This class is an experiential learning program for people experiencing a mental health challenge who are interested in establishing and maintaining their wellness and recovery. Peer-to-Peer consists of eight two-hour units and is taught by a team of two trained teachers and a volunteer support person, all of whom are personally experienced at living well with mental illness.
name: NAMI Peer-to-Peer Class

application_process: Register as a member
description: Directory of resources for people with autism spectrum disorder and related intellectual and developmental disabilities in Washington State.
name: Washington Autism Alliance Resource Directory

description: Program open to solo parents and caregivers, couples, and co-parents caring for children with developmental delays and disabilities, with kids aged 0-3 years old. This pilot peer-support program is offered as an 8-week series, and meets virtually.
name: Little Wonders Program

description: Commodity food program for income eligible Native Americans and non-tribal people who live on the reservation.
name: Lummi Food Bank

schedules.description: Closed the first Friday of each month.

description: If you are a victim of a scam or have been taken advantage of by a lender, call CLEAR to talk to an attorney who will screen you for eligibility, may be able to offer you initial legal advice, and may refer you to LAW Advocates for assistance from a volunteer attorney.
name: Assistance for Victims of Scams or Fraud

description: Prepares and serves hot, home cooked meals for the community. Currently providing lunch every Wednesday and Thursday at Faith Lutheran Church.
name: Maple Alley Inn

description: Provides library services state-wide, at the library and by mail, to any Washington resident unable to read standard print material due to blindness, visual impairment, deaf-blindness, physical disability (cannot hold a book or turn pages), or reading disability.
name: Washington Talking Book and Braille Library

description: Helps individuals diagnosed with severe mental illness meet their personal vocational goals. Employment Services assess vocational interests and provide job development, career exploration, resume assistance, and interview preparation using an evidence-based supported employment model to further client development.
name: Employment Services - LWC

application_process: You can apply for Cash Assistance online at washingtonconnection.org, by phone, or at your local Community Services Office.
description: Provides access to essential needs items and potential rental assistance for low-income individuals who are unable to work for at least 90 days due to a physical and/or mental incapacity.
name: Housing and Essential Needs (HEN)

description: Online directory of family-friendly things to do with kids in Whatcom County. Categories include indoor activities, outdoor activities, sports and swim, schools, camps, classes, and more.
name: Whatcom Kid Insider

description: Individual and group therapy provided by trained and qualified clinicians. Mental health-related assessments and referrals available, as well as case consultation and coordination with in-house and community providers to facilitate optimum client care.
name: Therapy - LWC

application_process: Apply online, or request an application in person. You can apply any time of the year. While the majority of children begin at the start of the traditional school year, whenever vacancies are available they are filled by families that have completed the eligibility process.
description: With no cost for families that qualify, Opportunity Council offers preschool services throughout Whatcom County for children between the ages of 3 and 5.
name: Head Start

application_process: Check for registration information online. Registration typically takes place in November.
description:
A holiday gift assistance program for families living in the Blaine School District who are facing difficult financial circumstances. Gifts are arranged in a store-like setting where parents can purchase brand new, unwrapped toys marked down about 75%. Voucher assistance is available for families needing extra help. 
Registration typically takes place in November.
name: Blaine and Birch Bay Community Toy Store

application_process: Register online or submit an official registration form filled out by a parent or guardian.
description: Sends an age-appropriate book each month to all registered children in Whatcom County. All Whatcom County children aged zero to five are eligible for this free program.
name: Dolly Parton's Imagination Library

description: WIC is a supplemental food and nutrition/breastfeeding education program that helps pregnant women, new mothers and young children eat well, learn about nutrition and breastfeeding, and stay healthy.
name: Nooksack WIC Program

description: A non-profit fellowship of people who suffer from the disease of addiction. Groups meet on a regular basis to help each other stay clean and share experience, strength, and hope.
name: Narcotics Anonymous (NA)

description: An electronic technology program that can locate missing persons using a unique frequency associated with a particular individual. Enrollment in Project Lifesaver includes equipment maintenance, battery changes, and upfront equipment costs. This program is for anyone who might have a tendency to wander, but who might not have the ability to find their way home again including people with dementia, autism, Down's syndrome, and traumatic brain injuries.
name: Project Lifesaver

application_process: Application forms available online.
description: A year-round substance use prevention and mentoring program that meets bi-monthly on weekends, for youth ages 9-12 affected by the substance use disorder of a family member. All camp activities are provided free of charge.
name: Camp Mariposa

description: Support for obtaining a Washington State ID or Enhanced ID Card. Whatcom County residents at or below 200% federal poverty level are eligible to participate. Email for current clinic dates.
name: Access ID Clinic - Opportunity Council

description: Max Higbee Center members are paired with a Community Engagement provider to receive one-on-one support to introduce community resources and create lasting relationships, develop goals and strategies, and learn skills that will facilitate integration into the community. This program is contracted through DDA and must be approved by your case manager prior to program start.
name: Community Engagement Service

description: Social workers are able to help Veterans, families and caregivers with almost any need, from help with finances or housing to questions about treatment to just feeling overwhelmed.
name: VA Social Work

description: A comprehensive set of supports for community members living with dementia, as well as those providing their care. Services include a variety of support groups, art classes, memory screenings, and dementia-friendly events.
name: Dementia Support NW Support Services

description: Can diagnose and treat conditions affecting Veterans' hearing, speech or balance. These include hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness, as well as speech, language, voice, or swallowing disorders.
name: VA Audiology and Speech

description: Hands-on programs focusing on K-12, such as classroom presentations, shelter tours and service projects. Classroom topics include: compassion and kindness towards animals, dog bite prevention and safety, spay/neuter education, animal cruelty and neglect, native wildlife safety, animal identification (i.e. dog licenses/cat id tags), and safety.
name: Humane Education - WHS

application_process: Apply online.
description: If you own your manufactured or mobile home and live in a community that is closing in Washington State, you may be eligible for relocation assistance. Manufactured and mobile home relocation assistance is provided to eligible low-income households on a first-come, first-served basis.
name: Office of Manufactured/Mobile Home Relocation Assistance

description: A nation-wide, evidence-based service where certified parent educators visit families in the comfort of their homes a minimum of twice monthly to support parents in developing the skills and confidence needed to raise healthy, children.
name: Parents as Teachers

application_process: Download a referral form online, or call for more information about enrollment.
description: A free, supportive program for women having their first baby. When you enroll in NFP, you are connected with your own personal nurse who visits with you during pregnancy and until your baby turns two years old. This program has been proven to benefit the health and well being of families. First time low-income moms in Whatcom County can enroll in the program prior to their 28th week of pregnancy.
name: Nurse-Family Partnership

phones.description: Prevention and Screening Clinic, Communicable Disease, and Epidemiology Phone

description: Clean and sober housing for men.
name: Oxford House Connelly

description: If you want to talk to an attorney about filing for bankruptcy, call CLEAR to talk to an attorney who will screen you for eligibility, may be able to offer you initial legal advice, and may refer you to LAW Advocates for assistance from a volunteer attorney.
name: Consumer Debt Clinic

description: Low-income families who receive assistance from programs like WIC and TANF may be able to receive a set of cloth diapers for free.
name: Share the Love Cloth Diaper Bank

description: A free clothing bank for residents of Sumas and surrounding communities.
name: Sumas Community Clothesline

description: Provides in-person or remote support and community resource referrals so that youth may explore, identify, and achieve their goals in employment and education.
name: NWYS Employment and Education Support

description: A screening to identify any factors that may interfere with a child’s learning, growth and development. The screening is also provided to help parents identify their child’s strengths and weaknesses and provide home suggestions and/or further evaluation if needed in any area of concern. Any child, birth to five, whose family or care givers would like more information about their child’s development can contact their local school district to receive a free Child Find Screening.
name: Child Find Screenings - LSD

description: Annual drive to gather donated winter coats, hats, gloves, and other warm items. Donations are distributed to local agencies serving people experiencing homelessness each winter.
name: Interfaith Coalition Winter Warmth Drive

description:
A non-profit hotline staffed with volunteers who all identify as part of the LGBTQIA+ community. Volunteers can help you when you
are struggling with coming out to yourself, coming out to friends & family, facing fear and isolation, or searching for local resources.
name: LGBT National Coming Out Support Hotline

application_process: To request meals for yourself or a loved one, complete the online form, or call.
description: Delivers up to 7 nutritionally balanced meals per week to homebound seniors throughout Whatcom County. Meals are provided on a donation-only basis, no eligible senior is turned away due to inability to contribute. description: Guarantees access to life-altering forms of immigration relief to children and youth who have been abandoned, abused or neglected by their parents.
name: Children and Youth  - NWIRP

description: CAP chaplains offer non-judgmental listening, emotional and spiritual support, and help assessing needs and making connections with community resources. Call to make an appointment.
name: CAP Chaplain Ministry

description: Postpartum Counseling is intended to help new moms find the support they need to adjust to all the challenges that come with adding a new baby to a family.
fees: Health insurance, sliding scale fee, and all major forms of payment accepted.
name: Perinatal Counseling - Hope and Thrive Counseling

description: A community-based effort to find solutions for individuals who are high utilizers of criminal justice systems. The aim is to lead people out of the criminal justice system and into intensive case management where those who are dealing with behavioral health issues can have their needs met appropriately.
name: Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD)

alternate_name: Making A Difference - Helping Other People Everywhere
description: Youth suicide prevention program with trainings designed by youth and the community. Training is based on current suicide prevention research, and aims to open up a conversation about suicide, help combat stigma surrounding mental illnesses and suicide, and help others learn how to identify and intervene with a loved one.
name: MAD HOPE

description: Operates statewide to investigate, advocate, and report on services to people with developmental disabilities. The program provides a range of services, including monitoring, information on rights and responsibilities, informal advocacy, and recommendations for changes in policy and procedures.
